title: Race Condition Crisis Before Major Launch
hook: At 2am, two weeks before our biggest launch, I discovered a race condition in our data sync layer that could have double-charged every customer.

situation.summary: Two weeks before the biggest launch of our migration project, I discovered a race condition in the data sync layer of our newly extracted microservices. This issue would have caused customer double-charges on every order, risking financial loss and damaging our company's reputation.
evidence: Discovery occurred at 2am during pre-launch testing.
Potential outcome: customer double-charges on every order.

obstacles.summary: The race condition was buried in a complex interaction between three newly extracted services. We had limited time to resolve this before the launch, and the 500k line legacy codebase added complexity. Additionally, the issue was critical enough to require immediate resolution.
evidence: Complexity of interaction between three services.

actions.summary: I immediately assembled a team involving Sarah from the platform team, Marcus from the orders team, and Dev, a contractor familiar with the legacy system. For 72 hours, we traced the issue across three services, ruling out initial theories and identifying the root cause. The fix was deployed by 4:17am on the third day, followed by two hours of validation to ensure stability.
evidence: Named team members: Sarah, Marcus, Dev.
Issue resolution timeline: 72 hours of intensive debugging.

results.summary: The fix prevented customer double-charges, ensuring a successful launch with zero customer-facing incidents. Post-migration, deployment frequency improved from bi-weekly to 5-10 times per day. The runbook I created for handling similar issues is still used by the team 18 months later.
evidence: Deployment frequency improvement: bi-weekly to 5-10x daily.
Runbook still in use after 18 months.

reasoning: The story was structured to open with the high-stakes crisis moment, followed by the obstacles and constraints that heightened the challenge. Actions were detailed to show urgency and teamwork under pressure, with quantified results demonstrating the impact and lasting prevention measures. Naming specific individuals and providing technical details added credibility and depth.
